quiz.title: Physics Grade 11
quiz.subtitle: Unit 10, Quiz 12: Photoelectric Effect & Dual Nature of Light
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which phenomenon provides the most direct evidence for the particle nature of light?
options: The photoelectric effect.
Young's double-slit interference.
Light refraction through a prism.
Polarization of light.
questions.explanation: The instantaneous emission of electrons by specific frequencies of light can only be explained if light consists of discrete packets of energy (photons).

questions.question: What is a 'photon'?
options: A discrete quantum of electromagnetic radiation with zero rest mass.
A negatively charged particle found in the nucleus.
A small wave that requires a medium to travel.
An atom that has lost all of its electrons.
questions.explanation: Photons are the elementary particles of light, carrying energy proportional to their frequency but possessing no mass at rest.

questions.question: In the photoelectric effect, what is the 'work function' (Φ)?
options: The minimum energy required to remove an electron from a metal surface.
The total energy of the incident light beam.
The kinetic energy of the emitted electrons.
The speed at which light travels inside the metal.
questions.explanation: The work function is a property of the material representing the 'binding energy' an electron must overcome to escape.

questions.question: If the frequency of incident light is below the 'threshold frequency' (f₀), what happens?
options: No electrons are emitted, regardless of light intensity.
Electrons are emitted, but very slowly.
The metal heats up until electrons boil off.
The light turns into matter.
questions.explanation: If a single photon doesn't have enough energy to overcome the work function, adding more 'weak' photons (intensity) will not cause emission.

questions.question: According to Einstein's equation, Kmax = hf - Φ, what does Kmax represent?
options: The maximum kinetic energy of the ejected photoelectrons.
The total power of the light source.
The temperature of the metal surface.
The wavelength of the emitted electron.
questions.explanation: Kmax is the energy the electron retains after using part of the photon's energy to escape the metal surface.

questions.question: Increasing the intensity (brightness) of light above the threshold frequency will:
options: Increase the number of electrons emitted per second.
Increase the maximum kinetic energy of each electron.
Decrease the stopping potential required.
Change the threshold frequency of the metal.
questions.explanation: Higher intensity means more photons per second, which leads to more successful collisions and a higher photoelectric current.

questions.question: What is 'Stopping Potential' (Vs)?
options: The reverse voltage required to reduce the photoelectric current to zero.
The voltage that speeds up electrons to the speed of light.
The energy required to turn a wave into a particle.
The potential energy of a photon at rest.
questions.explanation: It is an electrical measure of the maximum kinetic energy, as it is the potential needed to stop even the fastest electron.

questions.question: Einstein's explanation of the photoelectric effect proved that light is:
options: Quantized (available only in discrete amounts).
Infinitely divisible.
Strictly a wave phenomenon.
Created by the motion of the observer.
questions.explanation: Quantization implies that energy is carried in 'lumpy' packets (photons) rather than as a continuous flow.

questions.question: Who proposed that moving matter (like electrons) must have wave properties?
options: Louis de Broglie.
Isaac Newton.
Thomas Young.
Robert Millikan.
questions.explanation: De Broglie hypothesized that every moving particle has an associated wavelength defined by λ = h/p.

questions.question: The de Broglie wavelength of a particle is inversely proportional to its:
options: Momentum (p).
Electrical charge.
Temperature.
Color.
questions.explanation: The formula λ = h/p shows that as momentum increases, the associated wavelength decreases.

questions.question: Why don't we observe wave properties for a baseball thrown at 90 mph?
options: Its momentum is so large that its wavelength is too small to detect.
Macroscopic objects do not have wavelengths.
Wave properties only exist in a vacuum.
Baseballs are made of insulators.
questions.explanation: Due to its large mass, a baseball's wavelength is significantly smaller than an atom, making diffraction unobservable.

questions.question: The Compton Effect proved that photons:
options: Carry momentum and can 'collide' like particles.
Are actually made of electrons.
Cannot travel through metals.
Always speed up after a collision.
questions.explanation: The change in wavelength of scattered X-rays showed that momentum was transferred between the light and the electron.

questions.question: What is 'Wave-Particle Duality'?
options: The concept that light and matter exhibit both wave and particle properties.
The idea that light is a wave by day and a particle by night.
The theory that light is made of two distinct types of particles.
The mathematical process of doubling a wave's frequency.
questions.explanation: It is the core principle of quantum mechanics that entities possess both wave-like and particle-like characteristics.

questions.question: Which experiment most clearly demonstrates the wave nature of electrons?
options: Electron diffraction by a crystal lattice.
The Oil Drop experiment.
The gold foil experiment.
Measuring an electron's mass.
questions.explanation: When electrons pass through a crystal, they create an interference pattern, which is a definitive wave behavior.

questions.question: A photon of ultraviolet light has more momentum than red light because:
options: It has a higher frequency and shorter wavelength.
It travels faster than red light.
It has more rest mass than red light.
Ultraviolet photons are physically larger.
questions.explanation: According to p = h/λ, a smaller wavelength (higher frequency) results in higher momentum.

questions.question: What happens to a photon's wavelength after Compton scattering?
options: Its wavelength increases.
Its wavelength decreases.
Its wavelength stays the same.
It becomes zero.
questions.explanation: The photon loses energy to the electron; lower energy results in a longer (increased) wavelength.

questions.question: If you double the frequency of light hitting a metal, Kmax will:
options: Increase to more than double its original value.
Exactly double.
Stay the same.
Decrease by half.
questions.explanation: Because Kmax = hf - Φ, doubling hf results in a larger-than-double increase in the remainder.

questions.question: In the photoelectric effect, 'intensity' corresponds to:
options: The number of photons arriving per unit time.
The energy of each individual photon.
The frequency of the light waves.
The wavelength of the light waves.
questions.explanation: Intensity is a measure of brightness, which in the quantum model is the rate of photon arrival.

questions.question: The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle states you cannot simultaneously know exactly a particle's:
options: Position and momentum.
Mass and charge.
Color and speed.
Temperature and volume.
questions.explanation: Due to wave properties, defining a precise location makes the wavelength (momentum) undefined, and vice-versa.

questions.question: Which is the correct formula for the momentum of a photon?
options: p = h/λ
p = mv
p = F/A
p = E/c²
questions.explanation: Photons possess momentum defined by Planck's constant divided by their wavelength.

scoreMessages.90: Quantum Master! You have a full understanding of wave-particle duality.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. Review the relationship between frequency and kinetic energy.
scoreMessages.50: Good. Focus on the difference between intensity and frequency effects.
scoreMessages.0: Needs review. Focus on the photoelectric effect experiments and de Broglie waves.
